author: seth_weidman
content:
Hey all, I loved the debate here: https://blockdebate.buzzsprout.com/767033/8842016-motion-security-is-about-maximizing-the-minimum-set-of-colluding-miners-anatoly-yakovenko-vs-dankrad-feist Dankrad did a fantastic job explaining ETH2. 
Is this an accurate set of "bullet points" comparing ETH2 to Solana, based on that interview?

Solana, it seems:

* Has a core set of “full nodes” which are constantly generating the proof of history and all listening to each other.
* It has a set of “secondary nodes” that simply “listen” to the proof of history chain generated by the other chains.
* The secondary nodes are thus dependent on the “full nodes” not colluding and having a mojority of them produce false transactions.

ETH2, by contrast:

* Will receive transactions and send them out to shards.
* Each shard will process the transactions and publish a fraud proof - some sort ot a hash that proves that a set of valid transactions were processed by that shard.
* If any shard receives an invalid transaction, it wll send reject it and possibly send some sort of message to the network that the transaction was invalid.
* If any shard publishes an invalid fraud proof, it will immediately be detected by the network.
